notes.text: Updated Red Hat JBoss Web Server 3.0.0 packages are now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and 7, Solaris, and Microsoft Windows.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Red Hat JBoss Web Server is a fully integrated and certified set of
components for hosting Java web applications. It is comprised of the Apache
HTTP Server, the Apache Tomcat Servlet container, Apache Tomcat Connector
(mod_jk), JBoss HTTP Connector (mod_cluster), Hibernate, and the Tomcat
Native library.

* This enhancement update adds the Red Hat JBoss Web Server 3.0.0 packages to Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and 7, Solaris, and Microsoft Windows. These packages provide a number of enhancements over the previous version of Red Hat JBoss Web Server. (BZ#1164678)

Users of Red Hat JBoss Web Server are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which add this enhancement.
notes.title: Details

notes.title: Terms of Use

publisher.issuing_authority: Red Hat Product Security is responsible for vulnerability handling across all Red Hat offerings.
publisher.name: Red Hat Product Security

document.title: Red Hat Enhancement Advisory: Red Hat JBoss Web Server 3.0.0  enhancement update

cwe.name: Selection of Less-Secure Algorithm During Negotiation ('Algorithm Downgrade')

notes.text: It was discovered that OpenSSL would accept ephemeral RSA keys when using non-export RSA cipher suites. A malicious server could make a TLS/SSL client using OpenSSL use a weaker key exchange method.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: openssl: only allow ephemeral RSA keys in export ciphersuites (FREAK)
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text:
This issue affects versions of openssl as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5, 6 and 7. Errata have been released to correct this issue.

This issue affects the version of openssl098e as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and 7. Red Hat Product Security has rated this issue as having Moderate security impact and does not plan to address this flaw for the openssl098e component in any future security updates.

This issue affects the version of openssl097a as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5. Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 is now in Production 3 Phase of the support and maintenance life cycle. This issue is not currently planned to be addressed in future updates. For additional information, refer to the Red Hat Enterprise Linux Life Cycle: https://access.redhat.com/support/policy/updates/errata/.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata relevant to your system have been applied and back up your existing Red Hat JBoss Web Server installation (including all applications and configuration files).

For details on how to apply this update, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

vulnerabilities.title: openssl: only allow ephemeral RSA keys in export ciphersuites (FREAK)

notes.text: A flaw was found in the way the mod_cluster manager processed certain MCMP messages. An attacker with access to the network from which MCMP messages are allowed to be sent could use this flaw to execute arbitrary JavaScript code in the mod_cluster manager web interface.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: mod_cluster: JavaScript code injection is possible via MCMP mod_manager messages
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability
